terms.definition: Technical documentation that describes how to use and integrate with an Application Programming Interface, including endpoints, parameters, and examples.
A centralized web-based platform where users can access, search, and navigate through an organization's technical documentation and resources.
A lightweight markup language that uses plain text formatting syntax to create structured documents that can be converted to HTML.
An automated translation feature that uses artificial intelligence to translate documentation content into multiple languages without manual intervention.
Software systems that help organizations capture, manage, store, preserve, and deliver content and documents related to business processes.
Software as a Service - a cloud computing model where software applications are delivered over the internet on a subscription basis.
An organizational structure in documentation platforms where content is arranged hierarchically with 'books' containing related documents and 'shelves' grouping multiple books.
A simplified publishing workflow that allows users to make documentation live on the web with minimal steps or technical configuration.
Data and metrics about how users interact with documentation, including page views, search queries, and user behavior patterns.
Comprehensive technical documentation that provides detailed information about API endpoints, methods, parameters, and response formats.
Technology that automatically generates spoken audio content from written text, typically using text-to-speech synthesis.
Electronic versions of documents and manuals that can be accessed, searched, and updated online rather than in print format.
The ability to include external web content, media, or interactive elements directly within documentation pages.
Small and Medium-sized Business - companies with limited resources that fall between small office/home office and large enterprise categories.
A file format used by Microsoft Word for storing word processing documents, commonly used for traditional documentation before web publishing.
